data.title: Extension details view "Contributions" unclear

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
In the Extensions details view, the section named "Contributions" is unclear. Sitting with the C++ extension team, they thought this would be a list of the developers who had contributed to the project. Given the use of the terms "contributor", "contributing", and "contributions" (GitHub, our release notes), this may be a  common misunderstanding.

We could change the title for that section to something like "Additions".

Another option would be to rename "Details" to "Readme" and "Contributions" to "Details". We mention README throughout our documentation and this is similar to the "Changelog" title which refers to the filename CHANGELOG.md.

data.title: Allow to collapse a tree recursively
data.body:
This is implementing feature request [#9456](https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/9456)

**Request:** `alt+click` on a folder and recursively expand/collapse children.

**Implementation:** 

- Allow a boolean to be passed to the `toggleExpansion` function to indicate if the action should be recursive. 
- Allow the `expand` function to take a boolean to indicate if the action should be recursive to match the `collapse` function.

data.title: Add search to generated in-product Markdown preview (release notes, extension READMEs)
data.body:
Would it be possible to add search/find to the in-product rendered Markdown previews? This would help navigation in the in-product release notes and long extension READMEs.

This came up during a meeting with the C++ extension team, where they worried that their README was getting too long for easy in-product navigation and would like the user to be able to search for the sections appropriate to their specific C++ configuration.

data.title: chevron matching in TypeScript
data.body:
currently all paired braces, brackets and parentheses are highlighted except for chevrons which TypeScript uses for type parameters/arguments lists

so please enable paired chevron matching and highlighting

data.title: Add "return to top" control to Extension details view
data.body: This came up in a discussion with the C++ extension team. They are going to move their setup and configuration steps out of our docs to their extension README. They were concerned that the README would be long and navigation would be problematic. They can add H2 header links at the top (like we do for our in-product release notes) but would need the same "return to top" support as our in-product release notes. The current implementation in the release notes are embedded HTML elements. It would be nice to embed these elements in all the Extension details view renderings. ```html ```

data.title: File | Save As closes editor
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.91
- OS Version:Win 10

Selecting menu:File|Save behaves the same as menu:File|Exit
Steps to Reproduce:

1. Open project
2. Open file
3. Select menu File | Save as

**Edit: File|Open also crashes the app**

![saveas](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/3818866/23075465/330693bc-f502-11e6-88ab-471322a06c10.gif)

data.title: Test: Keybinding support for tasks
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode -->

- [x] any OS @ramya-rao-a 

Complexity: 1

You can now bind keyboard short cuts to tasks. To do so simply add a keybinding with the command `workbench.action.tasks.runTask`. If no arg is provided a picker should show up. If an arg is provided the task should be executed immediately. Something like:
```
	{
		"key": "ctrl+h",
		"command": "workbench.action.tasks.runTask",
		"args": "tsc"
	}
```

Executes the task with the name tsc.

data.title: Chrome Debugger Can't Find "Variables" ID
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode -->

- VSCode Version: 1.9.1
- OS Version: OSX El Capitan

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Use the Chrome debugger and stop on a breakpoint. Leave it in this state then hit the reload icon in the debugger.

After a while, this output starts being shown in a loop:

```Error processing "variables": Cannot find context with specified id```

data.title: When in preview mode of a Markdown file, keep preview mode when browsing to a link (local at least)
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode -->

- VSCode Version: 1.9.1
- OS Version: Windows 10

Steps to Reproduce:

1. In the explorer, open a Readme.md file
2. When file opens, click the preview
3. When markdown is rendered in HTML format, click a link that opens a new .md file

Expected:
-> we are "navigated" to the preview version of the MD file

Actual:
-> the file is opened in edit mode - text is markdown notation

data.title: Review diff algorithm API
Ability to define a pane/column layout
data.body:
It would be great to be able to define a pane/column layout via options, for every time you open VScode.

EG I would like 3 panes open every time I open a new blank project in VSCode.

data.title: Open a new pane/column without a duplicate file
data.body:
Current behaviour: 
- opening a new pane/column opens the same file in the new pane/column. 
- With this in place, the UX is not the best. To work on a new file in a new pane/column, you have to close the duplicate file first before opening a new file.

Desired behaviour:
- ability to have an option to open an new pane/column as empty, without a duplicate file pane.

data.title: Typing an import makes TS unresponsive for > 30s
data.body:
Type the following, one character at a time (i.e. no copy-paste tricks)

`import * as viewEvents from 'vs/editor/common/view/viewEvents';`

Observe how errors show up and the entire language service is unresponsive for >30s.

Saw it on Linux, but I don't think it is an OS specific issue

This is highly annoying and blocks me from being productive while selfhosting.

fyi @jrieken

data.title: Offer a command to open a tree/list's context menu
data.body:
The context menu when invoked using a key binding only works in an editor.  If something else has focus like the file explorer and you invoke the context menu, you will get the context menu of the editor and not the item in focus for the file explorer.

vscode: 1.9.1
OSX 10.11.6

data.title: Pasted text copied from an interactive terminal should retain colors
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode -->

- VSCode Version: VS Code Insiders from 2/17/17
- OS Version: Windows 10

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Copy text from an integrated terminal window which has colored output
2. Paste it into Outlook
3. Observe that the text is pasted without colorization

Now that copied text from an editor pane retains syntax highlighting when pasted into a rich editor, is it possible that we could get the same behavior for copying text from the integrated terminal?  I'll understand if this isn't easy to accomplish, but I know that former users of PowerShell ISE will expect it since that editor provides this capability.

/cc @rebornix @Tyriar

data.title: Test: Exception widget
data.body:
- [x] win @alexandrudima 
- [x] os x @bpasero 
- [x] linux @mjbvz 

Complexity: 2

Refs: #16860
We have introduced a widget to show more user-intuitive experience when exception is thrown. When the exception has happened running the code, a widget appears that informs that an exception has occurred, and an exception type and message is presented.

Have a sample correct code that throws an exception. Run the program and verify:

- When running a program, exception happens and the widget with correct information is presented.
- Navigating through the call stack and coming back to the file (where exception happened) does not hide the widget.
- Navigating through tabs does not hide the widget.
- Dragging file with exception to a separate editor window does not hide the widget.
- Stepping through and quitting a debug mode hides the widget.
- Running multiple instances of the code does not break the widget.
- Make sure widget looks good for light, dark and high contrast themes.


P.S. Latest CSS changes are applied in the build higher than 
![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/2239563/23205025/c0e795b6-f8e8-11e6-893c-5e1466868251.png)
If you want to create a bug related to styling, please ensure you are on a higher build or build if from master branch source. Apologise for inconvenience.

data.title: Paste with syntax highlighting is not pasting empty lines
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode -->

- VSCode Version: VS Code Insiders from 2/17/17
- OS Version: Windows 10

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Write some code in a syntax highlighted language like PowerShell which has empty lines between real lines:

```powershell
Set-StrictMode -Version Latest
$ErrorActionPreference='stop'

Import-Module "$PSScriptRoot\DSCEngineering\helpers\LogUtility.psm1"
Import-Module "$PSScriptRoot\DSCEngineering\helpers\ToolUtility.psm1"

# In case of DevWorkflow, this script will be bin placed to <DscRepoRoot>\build\x64fre\bin\Tools
# Workflow for generating package to be handed over to OMS
```

2. Copy the snippet of code and paste it into a new email in Outlook.  The result looks like this:

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/79405/23068850/1356b2e0-f4da-11e6-9ff6-b0f28a81cd1f.png)

Notice that the two blank lines are not retained.

/cc @rebornix

data.title: [GIT] Rename "Clean" to "Discard changes"
data.body:
When I want to undo changes I've made to a file in VS code, it's possible to use the embedded git tools, right click a file with pending changes and choose "Clean". This option keeps confusing me, so I wondered if it might be an idea to give this option an easier to understand name.

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/4456201/23068566/788fd354-f524-11e6-99c1-4f74b599f2a4.png)

2. Open file from WebDav site.

Will do so next.  Will update if this resolves.

data.title: Fixes #16860: Improving exception experience
data.body:
I have added an exception widget that shows a thrown exception message in a debug mode when such occurs.

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/2239563/23068195/f8a04efe-f522-11e6-8c35-f73193f2b8d7.png)

Fixes #16860.

Also removed border colours from widget options and moved it to CSS. Pointer arrow for widget colour moved also to CSS from the code.

data.title: Output window does not focus on the last output line
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode -->

- VSCode Version: 1.10.0-insider
- OS Version: Win 10

Steps to Reproduce:

0. Initialise git repository in the project folder, work with some files (to produces git output in Output window).
1. Try to commit something that produces the following git operation error:
![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/2239563/23067049/ce41bf76-f51d-11e6-853b-8b061df9569b.png)
2. Press 'Show Output' button.
3. Output window does not scroll to the most bottom, where the error is most likely present.

Expectation:
Focus on the last line.

ping @isidorn

data.title: [bug] VSC intellisense stops working
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.9.1
- OS Version: Windows 10

Steps to Reproduce:

There is no specific step to reproduce this. Only thing that I think that triggers it is working in larger scss file. File has around 2000 lines.

And, intellisense just stops working in the middle of working in the file. After that, it wont suggest anything in any file, even colors stops appearing in scss file. I have to restart VSC to get it working again.

I disabled all extensions and same thing happens. I even disabled GitHub but problem remains.

data.title: Automatically collapse "import" block in files.
data.body:
On larger projects you can end up with 10 or more lines of "import ... ;" statements at the top of a file.

It would be really great if vscode could detect if the there's a huge block of import statements at the top of a file and treat them as a collapsible region, and automatically collapse that region when you open a file.

At it's simplest I would define an "import block" as

1. The only lines above the first "import" statement are comments or empty lines
1. Line matches "^import\b" 
1. Line is an empty line
1. Line is a comment
1. The end of the block is the first non-empty, non-comment line that does not match "^import\b" 

It might also be worth having a minimum size before imports are treated as a block/region. E.g. 3 or more lines.

data.title: autoClosingBrackets should not autoclose if already followed by another character
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.9.1
- OS Version: Win10

Steps to Reproduce:

The following variable (where | is the cursor) needs to be turned into an array:
```typescript
const names = |'bob';
```

I type `[` and the results is:
```typescript
const names = [|]'bob';
```

What I expect to happen is:
```typescript
const names = [|'bob';
```

In almost every case I can think of, when a bracket/quote is typed directly in front of an existing character it should not be automatically closed, as added that extra bracket results in more work for the editor. (IntelliJ behaves this way, and I think it's a good approach).

Surrounding selected text is of course, already possible, but if someone does just type it themselves the editor should respect that and not hamper the coder by added a character they most likely didn't need.

data.title: 3 color theme change events on startup instead of 1

Ctrl+C not working in "Open in Command Prompt" window
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.9.1
- OS Version: Windows 10

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Right-click on a file and click "Open in Command Prompt"
2. Run some longer-running command and try to Ctrl+C to exit. No reaction.

When I do the same with a cmd window opened from outside VS Code then everything works as expected.

Related to #9347?
